docs.lead_paragraph: The state attorney general’s office said yesterday that it would not file criminal charges against a Queens drug abuse clinic accused by state regulators of defrauding the state’s Medicaid program of millions of dollars. Officials with the attorney general’s office said that after a long investigation of the clinic, Community Related Services Inc., they could not prove that clinic officials had intended to cheat the government. On Sunday, the state Medicaid inspector general’s office and the Office of Alcoholism and Substance Abuse Services announced a $16.5 million fine against the company and issued 25 findings of “serious Medicaid fraud, waste and abuse.” Efforts to obtain a working phone number were unsuccessful.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Passing the Buck to Mom and Dad'' (editorial, Sept. 27): Under New York State law, dependent children can remain on their parents' policies beyond age 19 as long as they are enrolled in college. This law leaves many young adults who are not enrolled in college without access to affordable health care coverage.
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Re ''Passing the Buck to Mom and Dad'' (editorial, Sept. 27):     Under New York State law, dependent children can remain on their parents' policies beyond age 19 as long as they are enrolled in college. This law leaves many young...

docs.lead_paragraph: Assemblyman Alexander B. Grannis of Manhattan and Councilman David I. Weprin of Queens urged the State Senate yesterday to act on a bill that would make it easier for adult children to receive coverage under their parents’ health insurance plans. Current law allows parents to continue coverage of a dependent beyond age 19, so long as the child is attending college, until age 23. The bill, sponsored by Mr. Grannis and passed by the Assembly in June, would raise the age limit for coverage to 25 and remove the requirement that the child be a student. In June, the Senate passed a separate measure, sponsored by Senator William J. Larkin Jr., an Orange County Republican, that would allow, but not require, insurance companies to continue coverage of adult children up to age 25.

headline.main: Manhattan: Plan to Extend Insurance for Children
headline.print_headline: MANHATTAN: PLAN TO EXTEND INSURANCE FOR CHILDREN

docs.lead_paragraph: Representative Jerrold L. Nadler, Borough President Scott M. Stringer and Councilman Alan J. Gerson, all Manhattan Democrats, held a news conference yesterday at Stuyvesant High School to urge the federal government to pay for research, medical screenings and health insurance for students who attended school in Lower Manhattan after the 9/11 terrorist attack. They were joined by Amit Friedlander, who graduated from Stuyvesant in 2002. Mr. Friedlander, a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, recently received a diagnosis of Hodgkin’s lymphoma and suspects toxic dust from ground zero was a cause. Federal officials have acknowledged delays in helping responders and recovery workers who were sickened at ground zero, but the effect on students in Lower Manhattan has only recently received public attention.
